2.14.1.title: Overview
2.14.1.content:
High Pressure High Temperature (HPHT) wells require enhanced well control practices.

**Definitions (typical industry):**
- High Pressure: Shut-in pressure > 10,000 psi or MW > 18 ppg
- High Temperature: BHT > 300°F (150°C)
- Extreme HPHT: Pressures > 15,000 psi, Temperatures > 350°F

**Why HPHT Is Different:**
- Higher pressures require higher-rated equipment
- Temperature affects fluid properties and equipment
- Smaller kick tolerance (narrow margins)
- Gas behavior more complex
- Equipment limitations more critical
- Consequences of loss of control more severe

2.14.2.title: Planning Considerations
2.14.2.content:
**Equipment:**
- BOP rated for expected pressures (15,000 psi, 20,000 psi systems)
- Chokes and manifolds rated accordingly
- Casing and wellhead designed for full shut-in
- Accumulator capacity for high-pressure functions
- Temperature-rated seals and elastomers

**Drilling Fluid:**
- Stable at high temperature
- Adequate density achievable
- Rheology management at temperature
- Thermal expansion considered

**Wellbore:**
- Narrow window between pore and fracture pressures
- Tight kick tolerance
- Careful casing point selection
- Potential for ballooning (elastic wellbore behavior)

**Personnel:**
- HPHT-specific training required
- Experience with narrow margin operations
- Understanding of thermal effects

2.14.3.title: Kick Detection Challenges
2.14.3.content:
**Thermal Effects on Mud:**
- Mud expands when heated (apparent pit gain)
- Contracts when cooled (apparent loss)
- Can mask real kicks

**Ballooning:**
- Formation breathes with pressure changes
- Appears as flow on connections
- Not a kick but must be distinguished

**Distinguishing Kicks from Thermal/Ballooning:**
- Flow decreasing over time = probably ballooning
- Flow increasing over time = probably kick
- Use flow checks with careful observation
- PWD data helps identify true pressure changes

**Conservative Approach:**
- When in doubt, shut in and observe
- Better to shut in on ballooning than miss a kick
- Extended flow checks at HPHT depths

2.14.4.title: Shut-In Considerations
2.14.4.content:
**Pressure Build:**
- Pressures will be high - prepare crew mentally
- SIDPP may approach or exceed 10,000 psi
- Equipment must be rated for these pressures

**Gas Behavior:**
- Gas at high pressure is highly compressed
- Less expansion initially
- Still expands significantly as it rises
- Calculations more complex (real gas behavior)

**MAASP:**
- Calculate carefully considering:
  - High formation pressure
  - Limited shoe strength margin
  - Gas compressibility effects
- May have very limited working pressure range

2.14.5.title: Kill Procedures
2.14.5.content:
**Method Selection:**
- Wait & Weight preferred (lower casing pressures)
- Driller's Method acceptable but higher shoe stress
- Must complete calculations accurately

**Kill Weight Mud:**
- May require very high weights (18+ ppg)
- Preparation may take time
- Weight accuracy critical

**Circulating:**
- Slow pump rates typical
- Longer circulation times
- Pump limitations may restrict rate
- Equipment temperature limits

**Pressure Management:**
- Very tight tolerance
- Small errors significant
- Continuous monitoring essential
- Expert supervision recommended

2.14.6.title: Equipment Considerations
2.14.6.content:
**BOP:**
- Higher pressure ratings (15K, 20K psi)
- Temperature-rated seals
- More frequent testing
- Specialized maintenance

**Chokes:**
- High-pressure rated
- Temperature effects on operation
- May have limited orifice sizes
- Redundancy critical

**Drilling Fluid:**
- Weight materials readily available
- Thermal stability verified
- Mixing capability for high weights
- Volume reserves

**Casing:**
- Higher grades
- Connection integrity critical
- Pressure testing more stringent
- Thermal expansion considered

2.14.7.title: Risk Management
2.14.7.content:
**Before Operations:**
- Detailed planning and risk assessment
- Peer review of well design
- Equipment verification and testing
- Personnel selection and training
- Emergency response planning

**During Operations:**
- Enhanced monitoring
- More conservative decision-making
- Lower thresholds for response
- Expert support available

**Documentation:**
- Detailed records of all activities
- Pressure data recorded continuously
- Decisions documented with rationale
- Learnings captured for future wells
